Fundamentals of Geology","description":"

This course provides a sound basis in Geology to those wishing to pursue professional careers as geologists, mining and petroleum engineers and environmental earth scientists. It will also be of interest to those who wish to understand more about the nature and origin of earth materials. The fundamental properties of minerals and rocks and the processes by which they form are described. Geological history and structure and consequences for the formation and preservation of mineral, coal and petroleum resources are considered. Methods for the analysis, description and definition of geological materials and resources are provided.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9d86a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ae","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mapping Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to calculate and interpret geological structures through contour maps and structural properties of rocks.
Assessment: A multiple choice exam tests the students understanding of structure contours and their ability to describe and quantify geological structures.
Feedback: Group feedback will be given in lecture/lab time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0186a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0986a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4586a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c986a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3086a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961979","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Multiple choice and short answer question exam. Assesses understanding of key geological concepts from both lecture and lab content

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0186a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0986a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4586a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8186a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c986a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7886a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mineral and Rock hand specimen practical tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to examine various mineral and rock samples and learn the diagnostic physical and chemical properties.
Assessment: Two multiple choice exams tests the students ability to identify the diagnostic properties of minerals and ability to accurately describe the properties of selected rocks, and identify the diagnostic properties of economic minerals
Feedback: Group feedback will be given in lecture/lab time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0186a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0986a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4586a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc86a977dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Fieldtrip assessment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Assessment: Students are shown geological structures in the field, which they are to interpret through drawing and describing the geological and mineral properties.
Feedback: Comments and marks will be provided directly on submitted worksheet.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS1211 - Earth and Environmental Science","description":"

This course introduces theoretical concepts of earth surface processes, land forms, surface deposits and soils. During the course, you’ll explore and interpret the origins of the continents, oceans, atmosphere and the planet itself from a variety of perspectives.


This course examines the effects of environmental change, both natural and induced by humans on soil, water and the landscape. Our lecturers will introduce you to the tools required to investigate Earth’s environments.


Environmental Scientists work all over Australia, with the industry growing from 25,300 in 2018 to an anticipated 28,100 by 2023. Through the course, you’ll gain knowledge that can lead to implementing policies in areas such as infrastructure development, site remediation and resource management.


Your study is reinforced by field and laboratory-based practical work.

contentlets.description:
This course introduces theoretical concepts of earth surface processes, land forms, surface deposits and soils. During the course, you’ll explore and interpret the origins of the continents, oceans, atmosphere and the planet itself from a variety of perspectives.

This course examines the effects of environmental change, both natural and induced by humans on soil, water and the landscape. Our lecturers will introduce you to the tools required to investigate Earth’s environments.

Environmental Scientists work all over Australia, with the industry growing from 25,300 in 2018 to an anticipated 28,100 by 2023. Through the course, you’ll gain knowledge that can lead to implementing policies in areas such as infrastructure development, site remediation and resource management.

Your study is reinforced by field and laboratory-based practical work.

Are you interested in the natural environment and how humans interact with it? Understanding how different environmental processes influence atmospheric, physical and biosphere systems is crucial for understanding many environmental issues and is essential knowledge for careers in environmental science and related fields. This course covers a range of topics including climate and weather, landscape and soil evolution, hydrology, rivers and coasts, biodiversity and biotic patterns – both from global and Australian perspectives. Key environmental issues discussed include climate change and storms, land degradation, water resources and pollution, flooding, coastal erosion and bushfires. A major theme of the course is the interaction of humans with the environment and the causes of environmental problems and hazards. The course has a reputation for engaging lectures, uses innovative and interactive practical labs and a field trip to enhance an appreciation of a range of environments and issues.


Please note: Students are required to take part in a field trip and students will incur personal costs. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.

Throughout the term there are four lab exercises that are assessed. These tasks assess how students take theory and apply it into practical tasks

Feedback: Marking of assessments will be done by lab demonstrators. Depending on the nature of the assessment, feedback on assessments will be provided either on the Assessment directly when handed back or will be discussed verbally in a Lab Class. The tutorials are primarily designed for course/lab revision and to discuss assessment feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"27863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6b863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e3863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam focuses on content presented in the lectures, and assesses student understanding of this material

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6b863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e3863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5b863cf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Trip Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The Field Trip Report incorporates knowledge gained and tasks completed during the Field Trip and some lab content. This task assesses student ability to apply concepts leanrt in class to real problems, and thier ability to produce a written scientific report.

Feedback: Marking of field trip reports will be done by lab demonstrators and academic staff. Comments and marks will be provided on the Assessment directly when handed back and will be discussed verbally in a Lab Class. Students can also discuss assessment feedback in the tutorial classes.

contentlets.description:
Are you interested in the natural environment and how humans interact with it? Understanding how different environmental processes influence atmospheric, physical and biosphere systems is crucial for understanding many environmental issues and is essential knowledge for careers in environmental science and related fields. This course covers a range of topics including climate and weather, landscape and soil evolution, hydrology, rivers and coasts, biodiversity and biotic patterns – both from global and Australian perspectives. Key environmental issues discussed include climate change and storms, land degradation, water resources and pollution, flooding, coastal erosion and bushfires. A major theme of the course is the interaction of humans with the environment and the causes of environmental problems and hazards. The course has a reputation for engaging lectures, uses innovative and interactive practical labs and a field trip to enhance an appreciation of a range of environments and issues.

Please note: Students are required to take part in a field trip and students will incur personal costs. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.
contentlets.title: Environmental Systems, Processes and Issues

Human origins is an exciting and dynamic branch of science as each year new discoveries are made that rewrite knowledge of our ancient past. This course will provide an introduction to the fields of archaeology and prehistory, exploring the evidence for our cultural and biological origins. It will also provide a critical exploration of the basic methods and theories employed in archaeology and prehistory research. Students will engage with evidence from the cultural, fossil and genetic records and explore wide-ranging topics drawn from contemporary archaeological research. The course covers topics like why humans are apes, the features that define us as unique, evidence for when, where and how we evolved, stone tools and the Palaeolithic record of human culture and ecology, the Ice Age and its role in human evolution, the diversity of pre-humans and our extinct human cousins, human interbreeding with species like the Neanderthals, Out-of-Africa and the origins of modern human populations, the shift from hunting and gathering to farming, and the beginnings of urbanised settlements and civilisation.


Note: this course was previously offered as BIOS3711 but changed effective semester 1 2017 to GEOS2021

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"21be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a96192f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Social media research","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Working in groups of 2-3, students are required to undertake a short on-line research exercise to locate and summarise primary scientific literature relating to a topic on prehistory found via social media and to discuss how the research has been portrayed to the public. The assignment should presented as a blog or wiki and posted on Moodle. Marks and comments are returned to students within 2 weeks of assessment submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Three short on-line quizzes will be held to assess the basic knowledge students have obtained from the course. All quizzes will be open for one week and can only be attempted once during this time. Each quiz will comprise 15 or 20 minutes. Marks from each quiz will be released on Moodle within one week of the quiz deadline.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"25be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91be356bdb359850eb6b147a3a9619d7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

In each week's tutorial, students are required to contribute to the class discussion around the week's topic. They are assessed on thier ability to discuss conceptual issues in the course, and demonstrate critical thinking on the topic. Students that are not contributing appropriately in the first few weeks will recieve some feedback encouraging them to contribution to tutorial discussions.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"25be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a96190a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Each week starting from Week 2, students will work in a small group (2-3) in order to lead discussion for 30-45 minutes around the topics and readings for the week. Students should also draw upon the readings set for their given week or other material they have come across in researching the topic. They should come prepared with a set of questions that can serve as a basis for leading discussion, and be prepared to draw upon examples from the week’s reading and lectures (or more broadly) to illustrate these key principles. Students should not rely solely on the week’s lectures or readings but must demonstrate critical thinking on the topic.

Marks and comments from academic staff are returned to students within 2 weeks of the presentation

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"25be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a96192b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"69be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5be756bdb359850eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d9be356bdb359850eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS2021.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3421ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Wellington Caves Field Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students write a scientific report based on the field trip undertaken during the semester. Students must describe key aspects of work done in field and laboratory, and interpret their results with some explanation of their significance to the study. Reports are assessed on students' ability to concisely present and interpret their results, and the use of primary scientific literature to support their arguments. Marks and comments from course conveners are returned to students on the reports.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3421ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bc21ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Theory Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The final exam assesses student knowledge and understanding of all aspects of course

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3421ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7021ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bc21ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ab","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6821ea2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"45","description":"

Students regularly submit laboratory exercises throughout the term. These exercises are designed to test students' laboratory skills, understanding of lab and tutorial materials, and their application of acquired knowledge. This assessment includes a presentation of a group fossil project, as well as multiple written reports throughout the term. Marks and comments from lecturere are returned to the stuednts on return of the lab reports. For the presentations, verbal comments will be provided after the presentations as well as further written comments provided on Moodle with the release of marks.

contentlets.keywords: geoscience,biological earth and environmental sciences,archaeology,earth science
contentlets.description: The course offers an overview of life through time with a focus on Australian prehistory. The nature, functional morphology and evolutionary history of invertebrates, vertebrates and plants are presented in the context of Australia's evolving habitats and climates. Processes and places of fossilisation, evolution, time scales, approaches to assessing relationships and the plate tectonic history of the continent of Australia are important components of this overview of the history of Australia's unique biota. Practical work on the most important groups of fossils is an essential part of the course. Note: Up to 4 days of fieldwork at selected fossil sites will be part of the course and students will incur some personal costs.
contentlets.title: Life Through Time

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS2131","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2131 - Field Methods and Mapping","description":"

This course provides opportunity to undertake an extended field mapping exercise in a seleted area of the state. The course will cover practical geological mapping techniques, general field skills, and the integration of stratigraphic, lithological, structural and palaeontological concepts. Use of remote sensed and geophysical imagery of the area to be mapped will be included. This course may be run in conjunction with other universities. Note/s: A field mapping camp, up to 6 days in duration, forms the principal component of the course and students will incur some personal costs.


Assumed knowledge: first year geology

This course provides opportunity to undertake an extended field mapping exercise in a seleted area of the state. The course will cover practical geological mapping techniques, general field skills, and the integration of stratigraphic, lithological, structural and palaeontological concepts. Use of remote sensed and geophysical imagery of the area to be mapped will be included. This course may be run in conjunction with other universities. Assumed knowledge: first year geology

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS2181","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2181 - Earth Materials","description":"

An introduction to the nature and analysis of minerals, rocks and soils. Atomic structure, composition, properties and classification of minerals, with special reference to the rock-forming minerals and the clay minerals. Mineral analysis techniques including chemical methods and X-ray diffraction; application of isotope studies including an introduction to radiometric dating. Genesis, analysis and classification of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rock types; chemical weathering and rock formation. Optical properties of minerals and rocks under the polarising microscope. Assumed Knowledge: GEOS1211 OR GEOS1111

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS2241","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2241 - Peak Carbon: Climate Change and Energy Policy","description":"

Why are Australians among the world's worst per capita greenhouse gas polluters?
What has Australia done to reduce its contribution to global climate change compared to other nations, such as the US, UK and Germany? What are the major obstacles to be overcome before Australia can make deep cuts in greenhouse emissions, particularly from energy generation?


Exploring these and other key issues, Peak Carbon will give students a greater insight into one of the most important policy challenges confronting Australia and the world today.

Each lesson, students complete a short multiple choice or short answer quiz. Feedback is given immediately to allow self assessment of progress and comprehension of the material covered in that week's lesson.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb55","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb53","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"70a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb62","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Essay topics (from a wide choice of subject matter) will be discussed in the first week. The essay comproses 40% of the final mark. This assessment assesses student ability to understand, discuss, and synthesise ideas and arguments relevant to their chosen subject.

Marks and comments from academic teaching staff will be returned to students

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb55","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb53","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a0a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb56","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final in-class test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"19","description":"

The final test will cover all lecture and reading material. It will be short answer and multiple choice.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"20a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb55","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb53","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"28a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb54","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e4a6c2911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb5c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation in lectures","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"16","description":"

The second hour of each weekly lesson will involve small group work to explore concepts, debate and carry out new research in class that will be presented to the class in the lecture. Groups take turns to summarise their findings and present these to the class

Marks and comments from academic teaching staff will be returned to students

Why are Australians among the world's worst per capita greenhouse gas polluters?
What has Australia done to reduce its contribution to global climate change compared to other nations, such as the US, UK and Germany? What are the major obstacles to be overcome before Australia can make deep cuts in greenhouse emissions, particularly from energy generation?

Exploring these and other key issues, Peak Carbon will give students a greater insight into one of the most important policy challenges confronting Australia and the world today.
contentlets.title: Peak Carbon: Climate Change and Energy Policy

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS2291","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2291 - Earth's Interconnections","description":"

GEOS2291 focuses on developing your understanding of how air and water move through the landscape and influence biogeochemical processes and ecosystems – both locally and globally. The course covers global water and energy cycles, measuring air and water quality and fluxes, water geochemical processes, microbiological biochemical reactions and gas production, and monitoring ecosystems for signs of environmental stress.


Measuring air and water quality, gauging fluxes, and assimilating information on biogeochemical processes is critical for improving our knowledge of Earth’s processes, assessing ecosystem health and quantifying the impact of human activities. Many human activities are locally altering air, surface water, soil, and groundwater quality. Case studies will be presented on monitoring the impact of agricultural, manufacturing, mining, coal seam gas, oil, and gas developments.  The theory and methods of analysis presented in lectures will be linked to your own field measurements and data interpretation at case study sites in Sydney.


Water fluxes and biogeochemical processes control ecosystems. Example studies will be presented that highlight how river and wetland function under normal climatic variability, and how such ecosystems are stressed by dam construction and alterations to flow regimes.  


GEOS2291 will prepare you for research in hydrology, hydrogeology, geochemistry, biogeosciences, and ecosystem sciences, or careers in land and water management, agriculture, contaminated land remediation, greenhouse gas monitoring, and environmental impact assessments of urban, agricultural, mining, oil, and gas developments.


Assumed Knowledge: BIOS1301, GEOS1211, or GEOS1701 are recommended but not required.

A two hour examination on material presented throughout the course.


Individual feedback if requested by the student.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4366f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d366f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"db66f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3266f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961923","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Statistical Analysis of Hydrological Data","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Self guided lessons, tutorials and exercises using Mathematica notebooks. Students learn how to write short computer programs for analyzing hydrological data sets to determine spatial and temporal trends.

Mathematica notebooks engage students in an interactive teaching and learning environment.


Step-by-Step worked solutions. There is a discussion about the solutions held at the end of the computer lab.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4366f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3266f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Scientific Poster: An analysis of field measurements","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students present a Scientific Poster. The poster is to be in the style of those presented at the American Geophysical Union (AGU; http://sites.agu.org) or European Geosciences Union (EGU; https://www.egu.eu) conferences.

The poster will focus on the processing and interpretation of one of the data sets collected during the field trips:

- The geological setting and hydrogeological parameters of Centennial Parklands

- Air quality measurements throughout Sydney (sources and sinks of greenhouse gases)

- Water quality measurements in Centennial Parklands

- Plant water use in Centennial Parklands


Students will be provided with a grading sheet that assesses
• The visual layout and effectiveness of communication
• Quality of data analysis (appropriate method, handling of units and errors)
• Adherence to the scientific method: background, method, results, discussion and conclusion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4366f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8f66f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961964","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c766f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"d366f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"db66f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"be66f4f7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961919","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Centennial Park Ecological Survey","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

A report on the ecology of the ponds in Centennial Parklands, with particular reference to the impact of water quality on the biota.


Comments written on the submitted report. A general discussion in lectures.

Australian Cultural and Social Environments","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2021/ENVS2030","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"ENVS2030","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2641 - Urban Environments","description":"

This course provides an overview of human geography approaches to understanding urban environments in Australia and beyond. Contextualising cities as part of wider environmental understandings and concerns, this course considers the changes to thinking about urbanism over time. Case studies engage the varied and multiple experiences of urbanism, by for instance, class, ethnicity, gender, sexuality and so on, but also in times of increasing natural hazards and environmental awareness. Contemporary perspectives include (post)colonialism, critical race theory, environmentalism and consumerism, and new approaches to nature. Students will experience data generation using various quantitative and qualitative methodologies.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"14cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619d1","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

During the course field trip, students assess gentrification of a field site. Students then carry out research for a ‘field report’ based on these investigations. The report will show evidence of aspects of contemporary change in urban Darlington/Redfern and Chippendale area, focusing on a discussion of economic, social and symbolic transformations within the urban environment using primary and secondary sources of data. Primary data will be gathered collectively and reports must be written and submitted individually. Research methods include historical framing using ABS & REI data, gentrification mapping using cadastral maps, graphing semantic differentials using descriptive word pairs supplemented with Photo-Assay, and media analysis of representations of the area over time, including news media and property advertising.

Marks and comments will be provided to students within two weeks of submission.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"18cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d8cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0ccf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961980","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial work","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In the first part of this assessment, each week, students submit a one page summary of the assigned tutorial readings for that week. These are peer-assessed for content, meaning that the students must provide evidence of having thoroughly read the set readings, and are returned with comments at the end of the class.

In the second part of this assessment, once during the term, students present the week's topic to the tutorial class. One week after this presentation, students submit a short essay on the topic. Only this essay, not the presentation, is assessed. Students are assessed on the content and theoretical and conceptual understanding of the tutorial topic, and whether they have provided a clear conceptual link to broader issues in the field. Marks and feedback are provided to all students at the end of the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"18cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ccf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d8cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"44cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

The final quiz assesses student comprehension of all aspects of the course. Marks are provided one week after submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"18cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9ccf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d8cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c0cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619af","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students choose one of two topics provided, and write a 2000 word essay on the topic. They are required to set out an argument, based on evidence, and then proceed to argue a case logically.  Marks will be based on thoroughness of the research and the rigour exhibited within the essay narrative. Marks and comments will be provided to students within two weeks of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"40cf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a9619c5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f3bf4b2bdbf1d850eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS2641.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"366902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb53","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Major Report is a written document that is submitted at the end of week 8.

The report aims to consolidate understanding of some plant communities in the Sydney Basin and the factors that influence their distribution, properties, the changes associated with European development and how to assess the legal threatened status of vegetation communities. One aspect of the report is to assess skills developed in several of the labs.

The assessment is based on interpretation of data analyses (completed in labs), quality of written work and use of relevant literature.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"be6902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb50","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"766902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb57","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

This is a short report that the students complete from a list of potential topics. The course convener discusses potential topics with each student (in week 1-3 workshops) and they choose a topic that suits their interests etc.

The assessment criteria this assignment is made clear in an online document and a marking rubric is provided (on Moodle).

This assignment is a short essay format. Each of the topics presents a question and students need to research and write a short essay addressing this question. Assessment is on the basis of quality of answer, in relation to scientific literature and patterns (in climate or vegetation.)

This report is due at the start of week 7 (immediately after the study break).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"876902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb5e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Climatic variability across Sydney","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This is a relatively short assignment and it is submitted (assessed and returned) before the census date (and so submitted at the end of week 3).

This assignment also builds on a lab, and so assesses their understanding of that content. The assignment requires students to select sites, download climatic data representing a transect across Sydney, summarise trends and then asks a series of short questions to assess their intpretation of the data. This assignment builds a better understanding of the climatic environment in Sydney, and this is then further applied to the controls of vegetation in the region.

The assessment is primarily on the basis of the students correctly interpreting the trends in the data and offering satisfactory explanations. Students have the option of using igrphs or tables to illustrate trends. Very good students also use quantitative descriptions of trends. Use of scientific literature is also assessed.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"76690e911bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb26","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"be6902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb50","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f6902151bf56010d5fb0fabdc4bcb5a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS2711.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Contemporary climatic patterns and controls in Australia. Development of the Australian vegetation. Elements of the Australian vegetation and their distribution. Climate change with particular emphasis on the Quaternary. ENSO phenomena and climatic variability in Australia. Fire and vegetation interactions. The impact of European occupation in Australia. Note/s: Field-work is an important component of the course and will involve expense to individuals.
contentlets.title: Australian Climate and Vegetation

The study of surface processes and landforms; especially those formed by river systems and coastal environments. The nature of surface deposits, sediments and soils and the interrelationships with landforms in different environmental settings. An emphasis on contemporary processes and factors of landform creation, as well as changes to landforms and surface deposits over time and in response to human modification of the landscape. Field and laboratory based work will provide practical experience in physical landscape evaluation and land management techniques.


Note/s: Students will incur personal costs associated with a three day field trip to the Kiama/Robertson district on the South Coast. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ad661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field trip exercises and report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

During the field trip, students apply course learning outcomes and skills in a field setting and using field acquired data. This includes a literature review of relevant theories and approaches to explaining a range of geophysical landscape features and processes that created them. Field data will be collected, analysed and interpreted for a range of physical environments, sedimentary units, soils and landforms.

Students will receive written comments and grades on all pieces of work submitted. Reports will typically be marked and returned to students within 14 days of submission. Model answers and general feedback for each assignment will be available on the course Moodle site.

This assesses student understanding and synthesis of all course content

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"25661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"65661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a1661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5d661dfbdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students complete four lab exercises over the term, worth 10% each. These test a range of skills such including: air photo & map interpretation; topographic surveying; description of sediments and soils; sediment particle size analysis; analysis of hydrologic data; data collection and analysis; interpretive questions and writing skills.

Students will receive written comments and grades on all pieces of work submitted. Reports will typically be marked and returned to students within 14 days of submission. Model answers and general feedback for each assignment will be available on the course Moodle site.

contentlets.description:
The study of surface processes and landforms; especially those formed by river systems and coastal environments. The nature of surface deposits, sediments and soils and the interrelationships with landforms in different environmental settings. An emphasis on contemporary processes and factors of landform creation, as well as changes to landforms and surface deposits over time and in response to human modification of the landscape. Field and laboratory based work will provide practical experience in physical landscape evaluation and land management techniques.

Note/s: Students will incur personal costs associated with a three day field trip to the Kiama/Robertson district on the South Coast. Details will be provided during the first week of the course.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS2821","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS2821 - Introduction to GIS and Remote Sensing","description":"

There has been a rapid growth in the use of digital spatial data in many areas of resource management and the environmental sciences. The aim of this course is to provide both a solid theoretical understanding and a comprehensive practical introduction to the use of geographic information systems and remote sensing in the analysis of digital spatial data, simple modelling using digital spatial data, and in decision support using commercially available software. Topics covered in the course provide an overview of the use of digital geographic information and earth-resource imagery for a wide range of environmental applications including geology, vegetation and forestry, agriculture, oceanographic and regional and urban analysis.


This course will be conducted through a combination of lectures, computer laboratories and field work.


Note:This course was previously offered as GEOG2821 Introduction to Geographic Information Systems.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6317f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a317f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e17f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Software training","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Throughout the term, students complete online training modules that train them in key skills in geographic systems analysis. At the end of each training course, students then complete a quiz to assess their understanding of these skills.

Feedback: Marks will be released via Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6717f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b17f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

Throughout the semester, students work on a major project. They summarise the findings of their project in a report due at the end of the semester. Students are required to demonstrate the meaning of their results, the rationale for project and methods, and the potential sources of error and their impact onthe conclusions. Students will be assessed on clarity and structure of arguments, how the work is discussed in broader literature, and map composition.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6317f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6717f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8b17f07bdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"DEM Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

Students wrte a report describing the development of their digital elevation model (DEM), and provide the appropriate metadata for their DEM. Students also make a map using a selection of data for the Smith's Lake study site.

Makrs are awarded for the quality of writing, and for the completeness, accuracy, and correctness of the metadata.

Feedback: Marks and comments from academinc staff on both writing and map construction are returned to students well before the final report so they can reflect on this feedback before the final report.

contentlets.description:
There has been a rapid growth in the use of digital spatial data in many areas of resource management and the environmental sciences. The aim of this course is to provide both a solid theoretical understanding and a comprehensive practical introduction to the use of geographic information systems and remote sensing in the analysis of digital spatial data, simple modelling using digital spatial data, and in decision support using commercially available software. Topics covered in the course provide an overview of the use of digital geographic information and earth-resource imagery for a wide range of environmental applications including geology, vegetation and forestry, agriculture, oceanographic and regional and urban analysis.

This course will be conducted through a combination of lectures, computer laboratories and field work.

Note:This course was previously offered as GEOG2821 Introduction to Geographic Information Systems.
contentlets.title: Introduction to GIS and Remote Sensing

Comparative biogeography studies the patterns that explain how life and Earth evolve together. In order to make sense of these patterns, this course introduces you to biological classification, evolution and deep time, which allows you to discover the processes that have shaped the distribution of life on Earth. The course, assessed on practical assignments, is aimed at students interested in palaeoecology, phylogenetics, terrestrial and marine biogeography and related professions.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6bc99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Functional morphology Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a technical report based on the material covered in the first three labs. This consists of a single practical report in which the students are required to classify specimens using quantitative techniques in a taxa of their choosing. This report consists of between 3000-5000 words and 10-20 figures. The reports need to be written to a high level explaining the aims, the systematic hypotheses, methods, results and discussion.

Feedback: Marks and comments will be provided via Moodle. General feedback will also be provided through discussion in class from academic staff

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"23c99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6bc99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"6fc99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a7c99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e3c99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17c99a2bdb799850eb6b147a3a9619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Palaeobiogeography report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

This is a research driven report. During labs, students undertake a major biogeographic analysis of Southeast Asia and Australasia. Each report consists between 3000-5000 words and 10-20 figures. Given that each student works on different taxa and areas, no two reports are the same. Students will be assessed on their ability to clearly explain and communicate the aims, the biogeographic hypotheses, methods, results and discussion.

Feedback: Marks and comments will be provided via Moodle. General feedback will also be provided through discussion in class from academic staff

Feedback: Marks and comments will be provided via Moodle. General feedback will also be provided through discussion in class from academic staff

Students will use a selection of research articles and sumarise key aspects of mineral deposits and preent aspects of that information in a 12 minute seminar.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b6216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619d8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mineral economics and Ore Suites","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

Students will 1) Analyse commodity trends and calculate mine profitability, and 2) desribe ore suite specimens and related these to deposit architecture and formation processes. Ore suite summaries will require a critical review of the literature to sumerise the features of one ore deposit.

Feedback will be provided on assignments by the course academics.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b6216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to:

- Identify economic and related minerals in hand specimen

- Identify economic and related minerals under the microscope.

- For various specimens from deposits, describe the mineralogy, structure, formation process, type of deposit and location within a deposit.

Feedback will be given in person by course academics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3e216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a961927","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7a216e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a96192a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619ff","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e2212e2fdbb99850eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will use research articles and primary literature to investigate the aspects of mineral deposits, including a desription of the deposit, method of deposit discovery, and the generic deposit type.

Feedback will be given directly on returned assignments by the course academics.

contentlets.description: The course provides an introduction to the nature and formation of mineral and energy resources. It is designed for those students wishing to work in the future as professional geologists, resource engineers and in other fields of geoscience. It covers: the geological setting, characteristics and genesis of major categories of metallic resources, the nature and origin of coal-bearing sequences and the generation, migration, entrapment and degradation of petroleum. Laboratory study of hand specimens, thin and polished sections is undertaken. Exploration and development methods are described. Note/s: Up to four days of fieldwork is a compulsory part of this course for which students will incur personal costs.
contentlets.title: Mineral and Energy Resources

contentlets.description: Most regions of the Earth's crust have been deformed over many millions of years, resulting in a complex three dimensional form. This course seeks to unravel this history through use of remotely sensed geophysical imagery and field mapping data. This course will demonstrate how large scale regional structures are inferred or measures from surface outcrop mapping. Note: A five day field mapping camp is an essential part of the course and will involve some cost to students.
contentlets.title: Earth Structures

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS3281","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS3281 - Applied Geochemistry","description":"

This course examines the characteristics, source and fate of metals and organic contaminants in natural and urban environments. Primary and secondary dispersion of elements and weather processes. Principles of vapour, water, soil, drainage sediments, rocks and vegetation geochemistry as applied to environmental assessments; aqueous geochemistry and contaminant modelling, with reference to Australian case studies. Introduction to sampling, analytical techniques and design of environmental surveys.


Note: Fieldwork of up to 3 days duration will involve geochemical surveys at a contaminated site and students will incur some personal costs.


Assumed Knowledge: students should have completed at least one of: GEOS1111, GEOS1211 or GEOS1701.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"fd048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a961912","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Sudents will summarise key aspects of environmental exploration and geochemistry using a selection of articles, reports, and scienitific publications. Students will present this inforation in a seminar. Seminar grades will be assinged based on the quality of the information in the seminar, and in the student's capacity to present an engaging seminar.

Feedback will be given in the moodle gradebook by the end of the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"f1048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"29044e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Exercises","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Three laboratory excercises will have students: 1) explore geochemical mapping; 2) modelling geochemical data and analysing plotting and explaining geochemical data, 3) an investigation on geochemical data quality where students analyse, interpret and summarise results in a short report, and 4) In investigation of isotope data and explain the trends in a short video.

Feedback will be given the week assignment submission for each of the four assignments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3d048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"79048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ed048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95044e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

There will be a field trip to Sunny Corner, NSW. Students will conduct a series of field tests (water chemistry, fpXRF, and other methods). Students will also examine the effects of AMD on stream sediments and soils and vegetation. Students will combine fieldwork with an extensive examination of historical datasets to ulicidate AMD issues and geochemical mapping methods.  Students will submit a 2000-3000 word technical report.

Feedback will be given by the course academics within two weeks of the report submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"79048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b5048e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ed044e6bdb759850eb6b147a3a9619f5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS3281.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
This course examines the characteristics, source and fate of metals and organic contaminants in natural and urban environments. Primary and secondary dispersion of elements and weather processes. Principles of vapour, water, soil, drainage sediments, rocks and vegetation geochemistry as applied to environmental assessments; aqueous geochemistry and contaminant modelling, with reference to Australian case studies. Introduction to sampling, analytical techniques and design of environmental surveys.

Note: Fieldwork of up to 3 days duration will involve geochemical surveys at a contaminated site and students will incur some personal costs.

Assumed Knowledge: students should have completed at least one of: GEOS1111, GEOS1211 or GEOS1701.

Asia-Pacific","description":"

The Geographies of the Asia-Pacific introduces a region that is as diverse as it is vast. The course draws on geography's renewed interest in locality, or context specificity. These 'new location studies' are informed by the 'cultural turn' and link broader structures to processes in local settings. This course aims to encapsulate some of the shared histories, the various experiences of colonisations, and some of the more contemporary consequences, as well as provide details about the uniqueness of context, of places and peoples.


Note: this course is offered every second year.

Students will study, interpret and explore the interrelationships between the various soil-forming factors and processes, the physical, chemical and mineralogical properties of soil and how soil is used and managed in Australia. The course introduces students to modern methods and applications of remotely-sensed geophysical data and GIS techniques to model and map the spatial distribution of soil properties. Laboratory work involves the synthesis of the theoretical components of soil usage and management using field (real world) data collected from northern New South Wales.


Assumed knowledge: GEOS2721


Note: A field trip is a compulsory component of the course and will involve expense to individual students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3a85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"12","description":"

Throughout the term, students work through a number of practical exercises during the lab classes. These problems are also further explored in the field during the field trip. These exercises are designed to allow students to apply the materials taught in the lectures to real world problems. Students submit two of these exercises to be marked. Feedback and marks from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of the presentation

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3e85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7685666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b285666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5685666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961918","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Festivals of knowledge","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"44","description":"

Each week, students are do a short quiz on Moodle which covers the lecture material and readings for that week. Marks are released immediately via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3e85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7685666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"b285666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fe85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a96194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae85666bdbf99850eb6b147a3a96191c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Poster and oral presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"4","description":"

Students are assigned a topic associated with Australian soil use and management. They then produce a scientific poster on the topic, and present their poster to the class in a short oral presentation. Students are assessed on the clarity of their presentation and the quality of the poster.

Feedback and marks from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of the presentation.

The final exam covers all course content. The students are required to answer both long and short answer questions

contentlets.description:
Students will study, interpret and explore the interrelationships between the various soil-forming factors and processes, the physical, chemical and mineralogical properties of soil and how soil is used and managed in Australia. The course introduces students to modern methods and applications of remotely-sensed geophysical data and GIS techniques to model and map the spatial distribution of soil properties. Laboratory work involves the synthesis of the theoretical components of soil usage and management using field (real world) data collected from northern New South Wales.

Assumed knowledge: GEOS2721

Note: A field trip is a compulsory component of the course and will involve expense to individual students.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS3731","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS3731 - Coastal Processes and Hazards","description":"

This course provides a lecture and field-based study of the processes responsible for shaping and modifying Australian and global coastal environments. The foundation of the course  is an application of the morphodynamic approach to understanding coastal processes and hazards. Topics covered include coastal evolution, nearshore waves, currents and sediment transport, beaches and coastal hazards and management. A strong emphasis is placed on practical applications related to coastal monitoring techniques. Fieldwork is an important component of the course and multi-day fieldtrip will involve expense to individual students.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"266999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961994","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Tests (exams)","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Class Test 1 (20% administered in Week 4):

Students are examined on lecture material from Weeks 1-4 in a supervised environment. The test is 1 hour in length. After marking by the Course Convenor, the students are provided with their test papers in Week 5 and feedback is provided by a review conducted by the Course Convenor. Test papers are then returned to the Course Convenor.

Class Test 2 (20% administered in Week 9:)

Students are examined on lecture material from Weeks 4-9 in a supervised environment. The test is 1 hour in length. After marking by the Course Convenor, the students are provided with their test papers in Week 10 and feedback is provided by a review conducted by the Course Convenor. Test papers are then returned to the Course Convenor.

These tests are based on course lecture content and address the following learning outcoms of the course:

  • An understanding of coastal processes and their relevance to hazards and contemporary coastal management issues
  • An appreciation of the variety of coastal monitoring techniques available and the logistics, planning, and data analysis involved in obtaining coastal environmental data
  • An ability to critically evaluate the role of human interactions in coastal systems and hazards and indicate key management strategies for sustainable maintenance of coastal environments
","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2a6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9a6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d66999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"da6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961932","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Course Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Course Project worth 30%:

This is a group project that involves both a written final report and a seminar presentation. Students are provided with the Project topic in Week 1 and the Report and Seminars are due/conducted in Week 7. The topic involves a coastal hazard assessment of an assigned region of the Australian Coast. Extensive verbal and written feedback is provided to the students by the Course Convenor via email (specific) and Moodle (generic).

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"2a6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9a6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d66999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"da6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0e6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Beach Imaging Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Assessment Weighting = 15%

This is an individual student assignment conducted in the Labs during Weeks 3 and 4. Students are provided with specific feedback on the returned assignment in a later lab class as well as generic feedback provided through Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9a6999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d66999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"466999f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Trip Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"15","description":"

Field Trip Report worth 15%:

Students are required to provide an individual report based on information and data gathered during the course field trip to the Smiths Lake Region. Students are provided with the report during the field trip (weekend following Week 7) and the report is due in Week 9. Students are provided with specific feedback via email and generic feedback via Moodle.

contentlets.description: This course provides a lecture and field-based study of the processes responsible for shaping and modifying Australian and global coastal environments. The foundation of the course  is an application of the morphodynamic approach to understanding coastal processes and hazards. Topics covered include coastal evolution, nearshore waves, currents and sediment transport, beaches and coastal hazards and management. A strong emphasis is placed on practical applications related to coastal monitoring techniques. Fieldwork is an important component of the course and multi-day fieldtrip will involve expense to individual students.
contentlets.title: Coastal Processes and Hazards
