Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS3733 - Environmental Geophysics","description":"

This is a 5-day field course run at various locations within Australia. Each day, there will be lectures on the theory behind various environmental geophysical methods used in the analysis of air, water, soil, vegetation or the subsurface. This will be followed by field measurements, data processing, data analysis and presentation of the results to the class.


Methods covered will include a selection of the following techniques, depending on instrument availability: time-domain reflectometry measurements of soil water content; optical spectrophotometry and the measurement of organic water quality; laser mass spectrometry of gases and water; x-ray fluorescence of soils and minerals; geophysics of weather and climate measurements, hydrological techniques (pressure transducer measurements of water level, acoustic drip loggers).


This course aims to provide each student with the necessary theory and skills to undertake geophysical measurements of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock. These skills are often required in research and consulting environments in hydrology, hydrogeology, climatology and environment sciences. Students will gain a theoretical understanding of the electromagnetic, optical, gravitational, acoustic and dynamic properties of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock; practical field experience in measuring the properties of air, water, vegetation soil and rock; data analysis skills; group work experience; public presentation skills; and literature research skills.


Note: A compulsory field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c221f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96191b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a report summarising their findings of the project conducted during the field trip. This assesses students' ability to apply skills in the field, data processing skills, data analysis, and report writing skills.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff will be provided after all coursework is submitted

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3121f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4e21f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8a21f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b521f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c621f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f121f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2921b47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Group Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students present the findings of their field investigations in a 15 minute presentation (plus questions form peers) during the field trip. Students are assessed on their presentation skills, their theoretical understanding of concepts applied in the field, and their data processing.

Students will mark each other (informally) to obtain understanding of assessment criteria for a good presentation. Feedback will be given on the day.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3121f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"4e21f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961911","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"8a21f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961914","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b521f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"c621f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f121f47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d21b47bdb751c50eb6b147a3a96199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a literature review of one field technique. This is submitted before the field trip, and therefore helps students prepare for the field trip as they have a thorough understanding of field techniques before employing them in the field. Students are assessed on their ability to synthesise scientific ideas and clarity of expression.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff within 2 weeks of submission

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"GEOS3761","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS3761 - Environmental Change","description":"

Imagine a world of wildly escalating temperatures, apocalyptic flooding, devastating storms and catastrophic sea level rise. This might sound like a prediction for the future or the storyline of a new Hollywood blockbuster but it is something quite different: it’s our past. In a day and age when we’re bombarded with worrying forecasts for the future, it seems hard to believe that such things could come to pass. Yet almost everywhere we turn, the landscape is screaming out that the world is a capricious place. But if we don’t tune in, the message is lost. We need to decipher the past and learn from it.


 


Past environmental changes and their impacts provide valuable insights into how our planet works. And it’s becoming increasingly clear that nowhere is really isolated from anywhere else.  From Sydney to the Antarctic, seemingly unrelated parts of the world are connected in one way or another.  The aim of this course is to provide you with a critical understanding of past environmental change and what this means for the future. To achieve this, we will use a combination of lectures, practicals and a 3-day field trip to delve into the past when our planet experienced violent swings in climate, sea level, ice cover, fire frequency and greenhouse gas levels.


 


Note:A compulsory 3-day field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred.

contentlets.description:
Imagine a world of wildly escalating temperatures, apocalyptic flooding, devastating storms and catastrophic sea level rise. This might sound like a prediction for the future or the storyline of a new Hollywood blockbuster but it is something quite different: it’s our past. In a day and age when we’re bombarded with worrying forecasts for the future, it seems hard to believe that such things could come to pass. Yet almost everywhere we turn, the landscape is screaming out that the world is a capricious place. But if we don’t tune in, the message is lost. We need to decipher the past and learn from it.

 

Past environmental changes and their impacts provide valuable insights into how our planet works. And it’s becoming increasingly clear that nowhere is really isolated from anywhere else.  From Sydney to the Antarctic, seemingly unrelated parts of the world are connected in one way or another.  The aim of this course is to provide you with a critical understanding of past environmental change and what this means for the future. To achieve this, we will use a combination of lectures, practicals and a 3-day field trip to delve into the past when our planet experienced violent swings in climate, sea level, ice cover, fire frequency and greenhouse gas levels.

 

Note:A compulsory 3-day field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred.

Theory and application of state-of-the-art remote sensing technologies including hyperspectral and radar remote sensing systems; standardisation of datasets using geometric, radiometric and atmospheric correction techniques; use of spectrometers, radiometers, scatterometers and spectral libraries in remote sensing analysis; introduction to geophysical remote sensing; fusion of multi-resolution imagery; mini-project work in either vegetation/land use applications. soils/geology applications or fluvial/marine applications.Assumed knowledge: GEOS2821


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2c0919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab work and reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"55","description":"

Lab reports are to be completed for three labs during the semester, where students answer lab questions, and include images/screenshots of results. Each student submits an individual report. These questions are designed to assess students' ability to analyse and interpret remote sensing data

Marks and comments from academic staff returned to students within 2 weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"200919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"2c0919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a00919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961933","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ec0919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"180919b3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students present the findings of their research project to the class in a final presentation. Students are assessed on the quality of presentation and communication skills

The aim of the final research project is to investigate an environmental remote sensing application, synthesising knowledge acquired through Labs and systematic literature review and applying it to a ‘theme’ of the student's choice (e.g. geology, ecology, land use change, surface hydrology, land degradation, etc.). The final project is a research paper to be complemented by a policy brief, as a way of summarising the report findings for decision-makers

Marks and comments from academic staff returned to students within 2 weeks of submission

The major project consists of the application of a set of spatial analysis methods to one or more data sets. Which specific analyses you use should be discussed with the lecturer, but should incorporate two of the main types of analysis (e.g. (1) a univariate analysis followed by a multivariate analysis, or (2) a univariate analysis followed by a spatio-temporal). The report should be structured like an academic journal article. Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments

contentlets.description: The field of Geographic Information Systems has expanded considerably over the past decade and the world has become very much richer in digital geographic information.  Vast amounts of geographic data are routinely collected, with approximately 80% of all data collected having geographic attributes. This course explores a toolbox of conceptual approaches and methods to model and analyse a range of highly complex, often non-deterministic, geographic problems. It explores a true enabling technology for the natural sciences in addition to a rich source of computational and representational challenges for the computer sciences.  This course emphasises a range of GIS and spatial data analysis approaches via a disparate selection of real-world applications.Assumed knowledge: GEOS2821
contentlets.title: Geographic Data Analysis

Environmental Impact Assessment","description":"Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is an important part of environmental decision making throughout the world. This course provides students with an understanding of the Commonwealth and NSW legislative framework for EIA; guidelines for EIA; ecologically sustainable development; impact evaluation in terms of environmental and socio-economic criteria; procedures, techniques and issues in EIA; future directions. Case studies of environmental impact statements (EIS) from the physical and human environment are used throughout the course. The course is valuable to students interested in environmental management.Note: Due to revisions of Geography at UNSW, all courses previously offered as GEOH3911 have been given an equivalent course code GEOS3911 from semester 1, 2007.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f927997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The final exam will cover the core themes of the lecture material and tutorial class content.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Introductory section for an EIS","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of this assignment is to gain experience in EIA report writing. Students will be assessed on their ability to write concise and accurate descriptions of their case studies, identify likely environmental impacts and critically evaluate relevant references.

Feedback: Students first submit a draft of their assignment (this is not summative). Tutors return these to students with constructive feedback to help students improve their writing for the final version. Feedback on the final assessment will be provided via feedback sheets from tutors.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5927997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"EIS incorporating environmental management plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

This assignment is designed to give students the opportunity to prepare an environmental management plan for an EIA report on their case study. Students will gain experience in researching relevant material, synthesising information, critical thinking and report-writing. Students will be assessed upon their ability to gather and synthesise relevant material.

Feedback sheets with comments will be available to collect from the academic staff after the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be asked to give short answers to approximately 15 questions based on the lecture material and advised reading/study. The questions are related to defining terms or explaining concepts.

Feedback: Marks will be returned at the beginning of the next tutorial, plus comments on short answers and class discussion with class tutors. The tests will not be returned.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961990","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"b127997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"fd27997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d527997fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS3911.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is an important part of environmental decision making throughout the world.  This course provides students with an understanding of the Commonwealth and NSW legislative framework for EIA; guidelines for EIA; ecologically sustainable development; impact evaluation in terms of environmental and socio-economic criteria; procedures, techniques and issues in EIA; future directions. Case studies of environmental impact statements (EIS) from the physical and human environment are used throughout the course.  The course is valuable to students interested in environmental management.Note: Due to revisions of Geography at UNSW, all courses previously offered as GEOH3911 have been given an equivalent course code GEOS3911 from semester 1, 2007.
contentlets.title: Environmental Impact Assessment

Students must complete a SWOT analysis. Tests students' knowledge of SWOT analysis and the application of this technique to a coastal industry

Feedback will be provided by tutors and academic staff one week after submission via comments and marks on Moodle via Turnitin

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"67f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aff32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ebf32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Briefing notes","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Throughout the semester, students must prepare a briefing note before each of the field trips. For each one students must summarise the environmental heritage of the site, the issues for discussion, and the management context of each site. Students are assessed on the structure, research effort, accuracy of information, and clarity and conciseness of written expression.

Feedback will be provided by tutors and academic staff one week after submission via comments and marks on Moodle via Turnitin

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2bf32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"67f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aff32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"57f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Round table discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

During one of the tutorials, the class will participate in a role play of an Environmental round table. Students must prepare in advance to role play one of the stakeholders involved in a case study. Students are assessed on their knowledge of issue under discussion, ability to present a viewpoint for discussion, ability to engage with other stakeholders.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2bf32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"67f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"a3f32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aff32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ebf32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9ff32e27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

Students choose a coastal resource management issue for their major project, During the term, students research this issue and prepare a management plan or a communication document. This assessment tests students' knowledge of the issue, and their ability to apply knowledge in a real-world scenario. Assignments will be assessed upon clear articulation of management issues, accuracy of science content, identification of appropriate management/ communication strategies, and clear description of management actions/effective creative use of communication tool.

This assessment consists of two parts - project proposal (20%) and final project (30%).

Feedback will be provided by tutors and academic staff one week after submission via comments and marks on Moodle via Turnitin.

contentlets.description: This course focuses on coastal resource assessment and management. Topics include: Australian coastal zone policy; coastal ersoion and conservation; soil and water acidification; global shrimp farming issues and management; oyster farming; causes of fish kills and fish disease outbreaks; estuary management; coastal water resource management; recreational and commercial fisheries; coastal wetlands. The course considers Australian and global perspectives on current and emerging coastal resource management issues.  Students participate in group work to develop skills in resource management.Note: Due to revisions of Geography at UNSW, all courses previously offered as GEOH3921 have been given an equivalent course code GEOS3921 from semester 1, 2007.
contentlets.title: Coastal Resource Management

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"GEOS6733 - Environmental Geophysics","description":"

This is a 5-day field course run at various locations within Australia. Each day, there will be lectures on the theory behind various environmental geophysical methods used in the analysis of air, water, soil, vegetation or the subsurface. This will be followed by field measurements, data processing, data analysis and presentation of the results to the class.


Methods covered will include a selection of the following techniques, depending on instrument availability: time-domain reflectometry measurements of soil water content; optical spectrophotometry and the measurement of organic water quality; laser mass spectrometry of gases and water; x-ray fluorescence of soils and minerals; geophysics of weather and climate measurements, hydrological techniques (pressure transducer measurements of water level, acoustic drip loggers).


This course aims to provide each student with the necessary theory and skills to undertake geophysical measurements of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock. These skills are often required in research and consulting environments in hydrology, hydrogeology, climatology and environment sciences. Students will gain a theoretical understanding of the electromagnetic, optical, gravitational, acoustic and dynamic properties of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock; practical field experience in measuring the properties of air, water, vegetation soil and rock; data analysis skills; group work experience; public presentation skills; and literature research skills.


Note: A compulsory field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"38eb6d65dbe8e41055a93324f3961956","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field group presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students present the findings of their field investigations in a 15 minute presentation (plus questions form peers) during the field trip. Students are assessed on their presentation skills, their theoretical understanding of concepts applied in the field, and their data processing.

Students will mark each other (informally) to obtain understanding of assessment criteria for a good presentation. Feedback will be given on the day.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"34ebad65dbe8e41055a93324f396195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"34ebad65dbe8e41055a93324f396195f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"34ebad65dbe8e41055a93324f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"38ebad65dbe8e41055a93324f396195d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3cebad65dbe8e41055a93324f396195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"3cebad65dbe8e41055a93324f396195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"01ebad65dbe8e41055a93324f3961974","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students write a literature review of one field technique. This is submitted before the field trip, and therefore helps students prepare for the field trip as they have a thorough understanding of field techniques before employing them in the field. Students are assessed on their ability to synthesise scientific ideas and clarity of expression.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff within 2 weeks of submission

Students write a report summarising their findings of the project conducted during the field trip. This assesses students' ability to apply skills in the field, data processing skills, data analysis, and report writing skills.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff will be provided after all coursework is submitted

contentlets.keywords: geoscience,soil,electromagnetic methods,water quality,water chemistry,water ecology,water use efficiency,gravity,climate,geophysics
contentlets.description:
This is a 5-day field course run at various locations within Australia. Each day, there will be lectures on the theory behind various environmental geophysical methods used in the analysis of air, water, soil, vegetation or the subsurface. This will be followed by field measurements, data processing, data analysis and presentation of the results to the class.

Methods covered will include a selection of the following techniques, depending on instrument availability: time-domain reflectometry measurements of soil water content; optical spectrophotometry and the measurement of organic water quality; laser mass spectrometry of gases and water; x-ray fluorescence of soils and minerals; geophysics of weather and climate measurements, hydrological techniques (pressure transducer measurements of water level, acoustic drip loggers).

This course aims to provide each student with the necessary theory and skills to undertake geophysical measurements of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock. These skills are often required in research and consulting environments in hydrology, hydrogeology, climatology and environment sciences. Students will gain a theoretical understanding of the electromagnetic, optical, gravitational, acoustic and dynamic properties of air, water, vegetation, soil and rock; practical field experience in measuring the properties of air, water, vegetation soil and rock; data analysis skills; group work experience; public presentation skills; and literature research skills.

Note: A compulsory field trip will be held and personal expenses will be incurred
contentlets.title: Environmental Geophysics

Includes case studies exemplifying procedures, techniques, methods and issues, and looks at trends in EIA in Australia and selected other countries.Note: Due to revisions of Geography at UNSW, all courses previously offered as GEOH9011 have been given an equivalent course code GEOS9011 from semester 1, 2007.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"eda92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Throughout the semester there are two group presentations. Students will be assessed upon their participation, teamwork, communication and presentation skills

Stakeholder forum - The purpose of the stakeholder forums is to develop skills in articulating a viewpoint and contributing to cooperatively developing an argument in a group context.

Feedback: Tutors will provide feedback and comments to groups via Moodle after class.

International perspectives of EIA - The purpose of this assignment is for students to understand an international EIA system and critically evaluate similarities and differences between systems and the implications for ecologically sustainable development.

Feedback: Feedback from peers and tutors is collated and emailed to students after the presentations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"55a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"91a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dda92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e1a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"01a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be asked to give short answers to approximately 15 questions based on the lecture material and advised reading/study. The questions are related to defining terms or explaining concepts.

Feedback: Marks will be returned at the beginning of the next tutorial, plus comments on short answers and class discussion with class tutors. The tests will not be returned.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"15a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"91a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dda92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e1a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"74a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"PG EIS Introduction","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The purpose of this assignment is to gain experience in EIA report writing. Students will be assessed on their ability to write concise and accurate descriptions of their case studies, identify likely environmental impacts and critically evaluate relevant references.

Feedback: Students first submit a draft of their assignment (this is not summative). Tutors return these to students with constructive feedback to help students improve their writing for the final version. Feedback on the final assessment will be provided via feedback sheets from tutors.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"15a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"55a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"91a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dda92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e1a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8da92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"PG EMP","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This assignment is designed to give students the opportunity to prepare an environmental management plan for an EIA report on their case study. Students will gain experience in researching relevant material, synthesising information, critical thinking and report-writing. Students will be assessed upon their ability to gather and synthesise relevant material.

Feedback sheets with comments will be available to collect from the academic staff after the term.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"15a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961940","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"19a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"55a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961952","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"91a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961955","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d5a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"dda92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961957","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"e1a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c5a92d7fdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/GEOS9011.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Examines environmental planning legislation and decision-making processes in Australia with special reference to NSW; the content and structure of Environmental Impact Statements and the stages in the granting of development consent; approaches to EIA with reference to the assessment of impacts on the natural, social and economic environments. Includes case studies exemplifying procedures, techniques, methods and issues, and looks at trends in EIA in Australia and selected other countries.Note: Due to revisions of Geography at UNSW, all courses previously offered as GEOH9011 have been given an equivalent course code GEOS9011 from semester 1, 2007.
contentlets.title: Environmental Impact Assessment

Marks and comments from academic staff returned to students within 2 weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0a5b666bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"465b666bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a96191f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8e5b666bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ca5b666bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7d5b266bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Students present the findings of their research project to the class in a final presentation. Students are assessed on the quality of presentation and communication skills

The aim of the final research project is to investigate an environmental remote sensing application, synthesising knowledge acquired through Labs and systematic literature review and applying it to a ‘theme’ of the student's choice (e.g. geology, ecology, land use change, surface hydrology, land degradation, etc.). The final project is a research paper to be complemented by a policy brief, as a way of summarising the report findings for decision-makers

Marks and comments from academic staff returned to students within 2 weeks of submission

contentlets.keywords: geoscience,geology,remote sensing,biological earth and environmental sciences
contentlets.description: Using a diverse range of case studies, this course demonstrates broad remote sensing applications in forestry, agriculture, natural resource management, wildlife conservation, environmental change, pedology, oceanography, geology, meteorology, and politics. Specific applications relate to the assessment of tropical and sub-tropical land cover change, ecosystem dynamics and biogeochemical cycles, vegetation biophysical properties, wetlands management and monitoring, fire, pollution, urban studies and cold region hydrology. Computer-based laboratories allow the students to explore a range of optical, thermal and radar data appropriate to particular applications, and provide exposure to practical image processing and interpretation techniques including classification, change detection, formulation of indices and derivation of empirical relationships. Practical experience with IDL ENVI and Erdas Imagine is provided.
contentlets.title: Remote Sensing Applications

This course provides an introduction to, and understanding of, the basic principles, structures, procedures and applications of geographic information systems and science. Topics covered in the course provide a comprehensive overview and practical experience in the analytical treatment of geographical information, including: information sources; data storage, representation and visualisation; projections and coordinate systems; the analysis of spatial data to generate new information; and the dissemination of such digital information through avenues including the internet.This course will be conducted through a combination of lectures, computer laboratories and field work.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"591051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961932","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Software Training","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Throughout the term, students complete online training modules that train them in key skills in geographic systems analysis. At the end of each training course, students then complete a quiz to assess their understanding of these skills.

Feedback: Marks will be released via Moodle

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"111051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"491051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"951051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"301051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"DEM Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students wrte a report describing the development of their digital elevation model (DEM), and provide the appropriate metadata for their DEM. Students also make a map using a selection of data for the Smith's Lake study site.

Makrs are awarded for the quality of writing, and for the completeness, accuracy, and correctness of the metadata.

Feedback: Marks and comments from academinc staff on both writing and map construction are returned to students well before the final report so they can reflect on this feedback before the final report.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"111051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"491051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5d1051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"951051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d11051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"301051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961911","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Throughout the semester, students work on a major project. They summarise the findings of their project in a report due at the end of the semester. Students are required to demonstrate the meaning of their results, the rationale for project and methods, and the potential sources of error and their impact onthe conclusions. Students will be assessed on clarity and structure of arguments, how the work is discussed in broader literature, and map composition.

Feedback: marks and comments from academic staff

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"111051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"491051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"5d1051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"951051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d11051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"491051fbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961915","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

contentlets.description: Approximately 80% of all data collected have associated geographic attributes, and there is an increasing need for people with the skills and abilities to manipulate and make sense of that information. This course provides an introduction to, and understanding of, the basic principles, structures, procedures and applications of geographic information systems and science. Topics covered in the course provide a comprehensive overview and practical experience in the analytical treatment of geographical information, including: information sources; data storage, representation and visualisation; projections and coordinate systems; the analysis of spatial data to generate new information; and the dissemination of such digital information through avenues including the internet.This course will be conducted through a combination of lectures, computer laboratories and field work.
contentlets.title: Principles of Geographic Information Systems and Science

The major project consists of the application of a set of spatial analysis methods to one or more data sets. Which specific analyses you use should be discussed with the lecturer, but should incorporate two of the main types of analysis (e.g. (1) a univariate analysis followed by a multivariate analysis, or (2) a univariate analysis followed by a spatio-temporal). The report should be structured like an academic journal article. Feedback from academic staff is provided within two weeks of submission, in the form of marks and written comments

contentlets.description: Geographic information systems have improved considerably over the past decade in response to a world that has become very much richer in digital geographic information. The requirement to build complex applications and simulations has become more urgent with the need to plan for a changing climate, to feed an increasing population and to provide pinpoint marketing analysis for business. This course explores a toolbox of conceptual approaches and methods to model and analyse a range of highly complex, often non-deterministic problems. It provides a true enabling technology for the natural sciences and a rich source of computational and representational challenges for the computer sciences. Topics covered include spatial dynamic spatio-temporal modelling; geostatistics; error analysis and data accuracy; network analysis; and machine learning and artificial intelligence methods in GIS
contentlets.title: Advanced Geographic Information Systems and Science
